details: “H” is the eighth letter of the modern English alphabet. It represents the voiceless glottal fricative /h/ as in 'hat'. In some dialects, it may be silent at the beginning of words. It originated from the Semitic letter 'ḥet'.

wordsData.definition: a shaped covering for the head worn for warmth, fashion, or protection
wordsData.example: He wore a big red hat on his head.
They live in a big house with a garden.

wordsData.definition: a female chicken, especially one that lays eggs
wordsData.example: The hen laid three eggs today.

wordsData.definition: a large plant-eating domesticated mammal with solid hooves
wordsData.example: The horse galloped across the field.

rhymes.name: H is for Hen (to the tune of 'Mary Had a Little Lamb')
content: Hen is walking in the yard, in the yard, in the yard.
Hen is walking in the yard, clucking all the way!

rhymes.name: H is for House (to the tune of 'The Wheels on the Bus')
content: The roof of the house goes up and down,
Up and down, up and down,
The roof of the house goes up and down,
